There are some important changes
in the coming lacrosse season. They
do not affect the varsity, which is, as
usual, going to add another championship banner to our Trophy Room
collection, but they have, nevertheless, an important bearing upon the
sport.
Last year a local lacrosse league
was formed: composed of ova sophomore and freshmen teams, Baltimore
City College, and the Mt. Washington Juniors. This year the Friends'
School has been admitted and there is
some talk of a team from Polytechnic.
The Hopkins Team of 1902 has in
the past offered prizes of cups or
medals to the members of the team
which should win two games in a
series of three between the sophomores and freshmen. This year, however, these prizes are to be offered
to the winner in this new league, and
it is somewhat doubtful whether or
not the inter-class games will be held.
In view of the fact that varsity
men cannot be used in the games of
this league, the two under classes arz
planning to combine forces and enter
but one joint team. This under-class
team will be lead by Max Paulus,
the sophomore captain, and its manager will be James Easter.
The object in extending the competition for the 1902 prizes has been
that it will have a healthful influence
iipon lacrosse in Baltimore and,by enlivening the interest in the game
among the schools, help in training
Voys—some of whom are sure to
come to Hopkins—in the sport. The
members of the League are raising
money among themselves to buy some
prizes for the team which will finish
second in the series. The future of
this new lacrosse organization looks
very bright, and some very interesting contests should be forthcoming.

The silver medals offered by the
Southern Lacrosse Leagues for the

Saturday afternoon the annual indoor track meet between the two underclasses was held in the Cage and
resulted in an overwhelming victory
for the second year class. The final
score gave the sophomores 44 points
against the 28 scored by the youngster
class. In three of the events, the
mile run, the 88o-yard run, and the
high jump the first three places were
all members of the second year class.
The individual stars of the games
were Freddie Lee for the sophomores
and Novack for the freshmen. Lee
literally walked away with the mile
run, lapping all the freshman entries.
In the 88o he won by a narrow margin from Schmeisser, who collapsed
just as he was breasting the tape. He
also won second in the pole vault,
giving him a total of 13 points won
for his class.
The "Freshman Giant,"Novack, was
the biggest individual point winner,
as he captured the pole vault, the shot
put and the broad jump, three firsts,
or 15 points to his credit. Fulton won
6 points for 1912 and Pieper's efforts
added 7 to the total of the new class.
One of the most exciting events of
the afternoon was the 30-yard dash,
which was so close that many thought
it was a dead heat, but the decision
was in favor of Pieper over Todes_
During the games the sophomores
created a diversion by singing some
of their songs: "We Have Sand in
Our Make-up," "The Clerk of Oxenford," and "The Old White Goose."
There was a large crowd of rooters
from both the classes, and many of
the old grads came up to see the
events. Several other fellows' sisters
were also present to see the prowess
of their brothers' friends.

THE NEXT DANCE

January 17, 1910.

The Cotillon Club desires to announce that the next dance will be
held on February the fourth. Furthermore, there has been a great deal
of difficulty caused by the non-payment, on the part of some, of the
money due on the dance in December. The committee goes to no little trouble to make these dances successful, and there is no reason why
hose who attended should cause further difficulty because of delay in
paying their dues. In consideration
of this fact, the club has felt justified in passing the following rule,
which will be strictly enforced in all
cases: namely, that no person will
be admitted unless he has a card of
admission from the Cotillon Club, and
that no cards will be issued to anyone who has not paid his back debts
and the dues for the dance which he
is to attend.

It is unfortunate that the library
of the Johns Hopkins University
contains no complete set of the
works of Rudyard Kipling. In an
article published in the last issue of

the necessity of college students'
posting themselves on the literature
of today, as well as on that of the
day before yesterday. It is true

this does not prevent the appearance
of his books on the library's shelves.

of usefulness extends to the graduate
students, and from them asks the
same support which it receives from
the undergraduate body. The venture of changing the character of the
publication to a weekly newspaper

improvement, and suggestions as to

welcomed. Among the graduate students registered in courses here there

college days edited papers of a similar scope and aim. From these The
News-Letter especially desires suggestions or personal conferences.

whatever concerning the editing of

help in making The News-Letter a

Mention was made in the last issue

London, will deliver four public lectures on "English Constitutional History." Dr. Prothero is a very prominent English scholar. He was formerly Professor of History at Cambridge, where he lectured on topics
connected with English History; at
present he is the editor of the "Quarterly Review," and is connected with
a number of learned societies. He
has published several books on English History, including: "The Life
and Times of Simon de Montford,"
"British History Reader," etc. The
lectures on "The James Schouler
Foundation" were delivered last year
by Dr. A. Lawrence Lowell, President
of Harvard.

PLEA FOR ALMA ',MATER
SONG
To the Editor of The News-Letter:
Has Hopkins an Alma Mater
Song? I must confess that when I
was asked this question I disregarded Mark Twain's famous words,
"When in doubt, tell the truth," and
took shelter in evasions. If I had
followed the advice of the humorist
I should have replied that I did not
know, and, as this letter is a confession as well as a suggestion, I am
obliged to say that I was ashamed of
my ignorance. I might add, too,
that I am willing to wager that there
are not two dozen students in the
University who could have enlightened me. Only after careful consideration have I reached the conclusion that Hopkins has not an
Alma Mater Song; indeed, it has
nothing vaguely approaching it.
True, we have songs—songs that
would be a credit to any university,
and this fact makes it doubly strange
that no one has ariun_to give us
something
that could stand beside the most cherished products of
Yale and Harvard and Princeton.
At these institutions the Alma Mater
Song is the most impressive feature
of every college event and one who
has seen thousands of men spring to
their feet and doff their hats while
the notes of the well known melody
poured from their throats never forget, the inspiring sight. Here at
Hopkins it is unknown.
A fellow-student has suggested to
me that the University Ode might
be considered the Alma Mater Song.
I have met few Hopkins men who
could recite Mr. Devries' admirable
lines, and I have never heard an attempt at singing them that has not
been extremely painful. This fact
brings home to us with convincing
force the realization that the Ode
does not meet the requirements of
an Alma Mater Song, whose music
should be as stately as that of "My
Maryland" and as inspiring as that
of "Dixie."
We have abundant material at
this University upon which to build
a song as immortal as the name of
Hopkins is destined to become. An
institution "mighty in its youth,"
with a glorious past and, as we have
reason to believe, a still more glorious future deserves a song that will
embody the pride and hope of its loyal graduates and students. Where is
the man who will write it?
Student.

WANTS TENNIS TOURNAMENT
To the Editor of The News-Letter,
Dear Sir:
Through your columns I would
like to urge the formation of an annual Hopkins Tennis Tournament.
There are a great many men at Hopkins who do not play lacrosse, and
would like to have a tournament. This
was proved last year when the Freshman Class held a tournament in which
there were twenty-one entries out of
a class of fifty. This was larger than
either the football or lacrosse squads.
And if the Athletic Association will
only do the decent thing toward this
game there is no reason why we
should not get up a good University
team; as St. John's is very anxious
to have a match.
If the Athletic Association would
appropriate seventy-five dollars,which
is very small in comparison to the
sum which it spends on Track, Football, Lacrosse—toward. a tournament
this spring, we could make the entry
fee sufficiently low to allow everyone
to go into it.
And as it has already been decided
to have sophomore and freshman tennis tournaments I see no reason why
we should not have a freshman-sophomore tournament, to take the place
of the inter-class lacrosse games
which will not be played this year.
In conclusion I would urge upon
everyone interested in tennis to make
it a point to see personally his class
delegate to the Athletic Association
and as his representative have it pushed forward at the next meeting.
And who knows, if they do the
right thing by us, we may some day
have a team to go up to the intercollegiates.
Thanking you for the space allowed me, I am,
Yours truly,
Student.

PLEA FOR ALMA ',MATER
SONG
To the Editor of The News-Letter:
Has Hopkins an Alma Mater
Song? I must confess that when I
was asked this question I disregarded Mark Twain's famous words,
"When in doubt, tell the truth," and
took shelter in evasions. If I had
followed the advice of the humorist
I should have replied that I did not
know, and, as this letter is a confession as well as a suggestion, I am
obliged to say that I was ashamed of
my ignorance. I might add, too,
that I am willing to wager that there
are not two dozen students in the
University who could have enlightened me. Only after careful consideration have I reached the conclusion that Hopkins has not an
Alma Mater Song; indeed, it has
nothing vaguely approaching it.
True, we have songs—songs that
would be a credit to any university,
and this fact makes it doubly strange
that no one has ariun_to give us
something
that could stand beside the most cherished products of
Yale and Harvard and Princeton.
At these institutions the Alma Mater
Song is the most impressive feature
of every college event and one who
has seen thousands of men spring to
their feet and doff their hats while
the notes of the well known melody
poured from their throats never forget, the inspiring sight. Here at
Hopkins it is unknown.
A fellow-student has suggested to
me that the University Ode might
be considered the Alma Mater Song.
I have met few Hopkins men who
could recite Mr. Devries' admirable
lines, and I have never heard an attempt at singing them that has not
been extremely painful. This fact
brings home to us with convincing
force the realization that the Ode
does not meet the requirements of
an Alma Mater Song, whose music
should be as stately as that of "My
Maryland" and as inspiring as that
of "Dixie."
We have abundant material at
this University upon which to build
a song as immortal as the name of
Hopkins is destined to become. An
institution "mighty in its youth,"
with a glorious past and, as we have
reason to believe, a still more glorious future deserves a song that will
embody the pride and hope of its loyal graduates and students. Where is
the man who will write it?
Student.

WANTS TENNIS TOURNAMENT
To the Editor of The News-Letter,
Dear Sir:
Through your columns I would
like to urge the formation of an annual Hopkins Tennis Tournament.
There are a great many men at Hopkins who do not play lacrosse, and
would like to have a tournament. This
was proved last year when the Freshman Class held a tournament in which
there were twenty-one entries out of
a class of fifty. This was larger than
either the football or lacrosse squads.
And if the Athletic Association will
only do the decent thing toward this
game there is no reason why we
should not get up a good University
team; as St. John's is very anxious
to have a match.
If the Athletic Association would
appropriate seventy-five dollars,which
is very small in comparison to the
sum which it spends on Track, Football, Lacrosse—toward. a tournament
this spring, we could make the entry
fee sufficiently low to allow everyone
to go into it.
And as it has already been decided
to have sophomore and freshman tennis tournaments I see no reason why
we should not have a freshman-sophomore tournament, to take the place
of the inter-class lacrosse games
which will not be played this year.
In conclusion I would urge upon
everyone interested in tennis to make
it a point to see personally his class
delegate to the Athletic Association
and as his representative have it pushed forward at the next meeting.
And who knows, if they do the
right thing by us, we may some day
have a team to go up to the intercollegiates.
Thanking you for the space allowed me, I am,
Yours truly,
Student.
